title: Kneeling in the Garden of Life
sub_title: The Beauty of a Humble Heart
devotional:
Old Mr. Abernathy was known for two things: his prize-winning roses and his even more impressive humility. He wasn't one for grand speeches or self-promotion; his actions spoke volumes. Every year, without fail, he'd enter his roses in the county fair, and every year, they'd win. Yet, he’d always deflect the praise, insisting it was the soil, the weather, or just plain luck. One year, a young woman, eager to learn his secret, asked him directly, "Mr. Abernathy, what's the real secret to your success?" He chuckled, his eyes twinkling. "Well, child," he said, leaning on his shovel, "it's simple, really. I spend more time on my knees than I do standing tall." He explained that true beauty, whether in roses or in life, came from tending to the roots, from recognizing his own dependence on something greater than himself.

Humility, in its purest form, isn't about thinking less of ourselves; it's about thinking of ourselves less. It's about recognizing that every gift, every talent, every success is ultimately a blessing, a gift from God. It's understanding that we are all interconnected, part of something larger than ourselves, and that our role is to serve, to nurture, and to give back.

In a world that often celebrates self-promotion and ambition, humility can seem like a weakness. But the Bible paints a different picture. Jesus, the ultimate example of humility, washed the feet of his disciples, a task typically reserved for servants. He taught us that the greatest among us should be the servant of all. Humility isn't about diminishing our value; it's about recognizing our proper place in the grand scheme of things – a place of service, of gratitude, and of dependence on God.
image_description: Close-up of rose bushes, with some gardening tools placed nearby, against a garden shed.
insights: The concept of humility is central to Christian teaching. Proverbs 15:33 states, 'The fear of the Lord teaches a person wisdom; humility precedes honor.' Similarly, Philippians 2:3-4 urges us to 'Do nothing out of selfish ambition or vain conceit. Rather, in humility value others above yourselves, not looking to your own interests but each of you to the interests of the others.' These verses highlight that humility is not only a virtue but also a pathway to wisdom, honor, and genuine connection with others.
prayer: Heavenly Father, I confess that I often struggle with pride and self-importance. Forgive me for the times I've sought recognition and praise instead of serving others with a humble heart. Help me to see myself as You see me – a beloved child, called to serve with grace and compassion. Teach me to value others above myself and to recognize that every good gift comes from You. In Jesus' name, Amen.
reflection: Where in your life do you find it most challenging to practice humility? What small steps can you take today to cultivate a more humble spirit? How can you shift your focus from self-promotion to serving others?
